content.text: Measure the distance \(l\) between the bottom of the clamp supporting the pendulum and the centre of the pendulum bob
Explain briefly how you measured to the centre of the pendulum bob as accurately as possible
Adjust the length of the pendulum until the distance \(l = 50.0 \text{cm}\)
Displace the bob slightly and release it so that it swings. Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation of the pendulum
Measure, and record in Table 1.1, the time \(t\) for 20 complete oscillations
Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation
Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the value of \(T^2\)
Repeat the procedure using \(l\) values of \(60.0 \text{cm}\), \(70.0 \text{cm}\), \(80.0 \text{cm}\) and \(90.0 \text{cm}\)
Plot a graph of \(T^2 /\mathrm{s}^2\) (y-axis) against \(l / \mathrm{cm}\) (x-axis). Start the \(T^2\) axis at a convenient value close to the minimum value of \(T^2\)
Explain briefly why timing 20 oscillations gives a more accurate result for the period \(T\) than timing 1 oscillation
In this experiment, you will investigate the period of a pendulum. Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2
Fig. 1.2
A pendulum has been set up for you as shown in Fig. 1.1
Measure the current \(I_{1}\) in the circuit
Measure the potential difference (p.d.) \(V_{1}\) across lamp L. Open the switch
Calculate the resistance \(R_{1}\) of lamp L. Use the equation \(R_{1} = \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}\). Include the unit
Place the sliding contact S on the resistance wire as close as possible to point C
Close the switch
Place the sliding contact S on the resistance wire as close as possible to point D. Point D is at the mid-point of the resistance wire
Close the switch
• Measure the current \(I_{2}\) in the circuit
• Measure the potential difference \(V_{2}\) across lamp L
Place the sliding contact S on the resistance wire as close as possible to point E
Close the switch
Measure the current \(I_{3}\) in the circuit
Measure the potential difference \(V_{3}\) across lamp L
Open the switch
Calculate the resistance \(R_{3}\) of lamp L. Use the equation \(R_{3} = \frac{V_{3}}{I_{3}}\). Include the unit
Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
Complete the following statements, referring to your observations and results
1. As the length of resistance wire included in the circuit is increased, the brightness of the
lamp
2. As the length of resistance wire included in the circuit is increased, the resistance of the
lamp
A variable resistor can be used in this type of experiment in place of the resistance wire
Draw a circuit diagram to show a variable resistor in place of the resistance wire. Include the ammeter and the voltmeter in your diagram
In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of a lamp
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
Fig. 2.1
Use the thermometer to measure the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)   .........  \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Place the thermometer in the hot water
Record in Table 3.1 the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\). Immediately start the stop-watch
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the water temperature every 30 s until you have seven sets of readings
Calculate the decrease in temperature \(\Delta \theta_{1}\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Calculate the average rate of cooling \(C_1\) of the water using the equation \(C_1 = \frac{\Delta \theta_1}{\Delta t}\),
where \(\Delta t = 180 \text{s}\)
Using Table 3.1, write down the temperature \(\theta_{90}\) of the water at time \(t = 90 \text{s}\)

Pour \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Place the thermometer in the water. Slowly add cold water, stirring continuously, until the temperature of the water in the beaker is as close as possible to \(\theta_{90}\). Record this temperature in Table 3.2 at time \(t = 0\)
Immediately start the stop-watch
Measure, and record in Table 3.2, the water temperature every 30 s until you have four sets of readings
Using Table 3.2, calculate the decrease in temperature \(\Delta \theta_2\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 90 \text{s}\)
Calculate the average rate of cooling \(C_2\) of the water using the equation \(C_2 = \frac{\Delta \theta_2}{\Delta t}\),
where \(\Delta t = 90 \text{s}\)
Empty the beaker
A student suggests that the rate of cooling of water depends on the initial temperature of the water
Write a conclusion about the effect of the initial temperature of water on the rate of cooling of the water, based on your results. Justify your conclusion by reference to values from your results
conclusion
justification
State two requirements when reading the volume of water in the measuring cylinder in order to obtain an accurate result
In this experiment, you will investigate the effect of the starting temperature on the cooling rate of water
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1
A student investigates the horizontal distance travelled by a metal ball after it rolls off the end of a plastic track. Fig. 4.1 shows the set-up
The ball rolls down a plastic track. The left-hand side of the track is fixed. The right-hand side can be adjusted so that the ball comes off the track at different angles
The student measures the horizontal distance that the ball travels from the right-hand end of the track to the point that it hits the floor
Plan an experiment to investigate how the horizontal distance travelled by the metal ball depends on the angle that the right-hand end of the track makes with the bench
You are **not** required to do this experiment
The following apparatus is available to the student:
· track with stand, boss and clamp
· selection of metal balls
Other apparatus normally available in a school laboratory can also be used
In your plan, you should:
· list any additional apparatus required
· explain briefly how you would do the investigation, including the measurements you would take
· state the key variables to be kept constant
· draw a suitable table, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
· explain how you would use the results to reach a conclusion
